edu.biu.scapi.circuits.garbledCircuit
Class FreeXORGate

java.lang.Object
  edu.biu.scapi.circuits.garbledCircuit.AbstractGarbledGate
      edu.biu.scapi.circuits.garbledCircuit.FreeXORGate
All Implemented Interfaces:
GarbledGate
public class FreeXORGate
extends AbstractGarbledGate

See Free XOR Gates and Applications by Validimir Kolesnikov and Thomas Schneider for a full description of the Free XOR technique, pseudocode implementation, as well as the proof of security. As they mention in that paper, a Free XOR gate with n > 2 inputs can be broken down into n-1 2-input XOR gates. Hence, we implement the Free XOR optimization for 2-input XOR Gates, and we leave it to the circuit designer to maximize the number of 2-input XOR gates.

The Free XOR optimization allows XOR Gates to be evaluated for free--i.e. without encryption, and thus significantly speeds up Garbled Circuit computations on large circuits with many XOR Gates. The technique dictates a careful way to choose the Wire Values. See the FreeXORGarbledCBooleanCircuit class where we construct the circuit and choose the values according to this procedure. Once the Wwire values have been chosen as such, evaluating XOR gates does not require encryption. See the compute(Map) method in this class where the computation is done.

Author:
Steven Goldfeder

Constructor Detail

FreeXORGate

public FreeXORGate(Gate ungarbledGate)
Parameters:
ungarbledGate - The ungarbled Gate that is to be Garbled. Since this is an XOR Gate using the Free XOR technique, no encryption is required for its Garbling. Rather, the GarbledWire values were carefully chosen in the @ code GarbledBooleanCiircuit} . See StandardGarbledBooleanCircuit and compute(Map) for the technical details on how this is achieved.

verify

public boolean verify(Gate g,
                      java.util.Map<java.lang.Integer,javax.crypto.SecretKey[]> allWireValues)
Description copied from interface: GarbledGate
This method tests an ungarbled Gate for equality to this GarbledGate returning true if they are equal and false otherwise. It is called verify since in general, when this method is used, the assumption is that they are equal and we are verifying this assumption.

Parameters:
g - an ungarbled Gate to be tested for equality to this GarbledGate
Returns:
returns true if the gates are have the same truth table and label, and false otherwise * @throws InvalidKeyException
